title: 3 Let's Grow! Listening
description: Dit is een methode die iedereen de kans geeft vanuit zijn niveau verder te groeien.

heading.content: Can Do Statements & links to assignments

items.content:
Navigation History: Let's Grow! Home > Listening Home

Go to Let's Grow! Skills selection

Do you want to become an A1 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

Do you want to become an A2 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

Do you want to become an B1 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

Do you want to become an B2 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

Do you want to become an C1 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

Do you want to become an C2 listener? Click here to get a bite-size overview!

A1

61 I can follow speech which is very slow and carefully articulated, with long pauses for me to assimilate meaning.
62 I can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to me and follow short, simple directions.
63 I can understand questions and instructions and follow short, simple directions.
64 I can understand everyday expressions dealing with simple and concrete everyday needs, in clear, slow and repeated speech.
65 I can understand numbers, prices and times.

A2

66 I can handle simple business in shops, post offices or banks.
67 I can follow changes of topic of factual TV news items, and form an idea of the main content.
68 I can identify the main point of TV news items reporting events, accidents, etc, where the visual material supports the commentary.
69 I can understand and extract the essential information from short, recorded passages dealing with
predictable everyday matters which are delivered slowly and clearly.
70 I can catch the main point in short, clear, simple messages and announcements.
71 I can generally identify the topic of discussion around me, when it is conducted slowly and clearly.
72 I can understand simple directions relating to how to get from X to Y, by foot or public transport.
73 I can understand phrases and expressions related to immediate needs.
74 I can understand phrases and expressions related to areas of most immediate priority (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment) provided speech is clearly and slowly articulated.

B1

75 I can understand a large part of many TV programmes on topics of personal interest such as interviews, short lectures, and news reports when the delivery is relatively slow and clear.
76 I can follow many films in which visuals and action carry much of the storyline, and which are delivered clearly in straightforward language.
77 I can catch the main points in TV programmes on familiar topics when the delivery is relatively slow and clear.
78 can understand the information content of the majority of recorded or broadcast audio material on topics of personal interest delivered in clear standard speech.
79 I can understand the main points of radio news bulletins and simpler recorded material about familiar subjects delivered relatively slowly and clearly.
80 I can understand simple technical information, such as operating instructions for everyday equipment.
81 I can follow detailed directions.
82 I can understand straightforward factual information and narratives about things you would normally discuss with friends or colleagues.
83 I can understand vocabulary, phrases and narratives that have to do with being in school, college or university.
84 I can understand vocabulary, phrases and narratives that have to do with working in a company.
85 I can generally follow the main points of extended discussion around me, provided speech is clearly
articulated in standard dialect.
86 I can follow a lecture or talk within his/her own field, provided the subject matter is familiar and the
presentation straightforward and clearly structured.
87 I can follow in outline straightforward short talks on familiar topics provided these are delivered in clearly articulated standard speech.

B2

88 I can use a variety of strategies to achieve comprehension, including listening for main points; checking
comprehension by using contextual clues.
89 I can understand most TV news and current affairs programmes.
90 I can understand documentaries, live interviews, talk shows, plays and the majority of films in standard dialect.
91 I can understand the main ideas of propositionally and linguistically complex speech on both concrete and abstract topics delivered in a standard dialect, including technical discussions in his/her field of specialisation.
92 I can follow extended speech and complex lines of argument provided the topic is reasonably familiar, and the direction of the talk is sign-posted by explicit markers.
93 I can understand standard spoken language, live or broadcast, on both familiar and unfamiliar topics normally encountered in personal, social, academic or vocational life. Only extreme background noise, inadequate discourse structure and/or idiomatic usage influences the ability to understand.
94 I can keep up with an animated conversation between native speakers.
95 I can with some effort catch much of what is said around me, but may find it difficult to participate effectively in discussion with several native speakers who do not modify their language in any way.
96 I can follow the essentials of lectures, talks and reports and other forms of academic/professional presentation which are propositionally and linguistically complex.
97 I can understand announcements and messages on concrete and abstract topics spoken in standard dialect at normal speed.
98 I can understand recordings in standard dialect likely to be encountered in social, professional or
academic life and identify speaker viewpoints and attitudes as well as the information content.
99 I can understand most radio documentaries and most other recorded or broadcast audio material
delivered in standard dialect and can identify the speaker's mood, tone etc.

C1

100 I can understand enough to follow extended speech on abstract and complex topics beyond his/her own
field, though he/she may need to confirm occasional details, especially if the accent is unfamiliar.
101 I can recognise a wide range of idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms, appreciating register shifts.
102 I can follow extended speech even when it is not clearly structured and when relationships are only
implied and not signalled explicitly.
103 I can follow most lectures, discussions and debates with relative ease.
104 I can understand a wide range of recorded and broadcast audio material, including some non-standard usage, and identify finer points of detail including implicit attitudes and relationships between speakers.
105 I am skilled at using contextual, grammatical and lexical cues to infer attitude, mood and intentions and
anticipating what will come next.
106 I can extract specific information from poor quality, audibly distorted public announcements, e.g. in a station, sports stadium etc.
107 I can understand complex technical information, such as operating instructions, specifications for familiar products and services.
108 I can easily follow complex interactions between third parties in group discussion and debate, even on
abstract, complex unfamiliar topics.
109 I can follow films employing a considerable degree of slang and idiomatic usage.

C2

110 I have no difficulty in understanding any kind of spoken language, whether live or broadcast, delivered at
fast native speed.
111 I can follow specialised lectures and presentations employing a high degree of colloquialism, regional usage or unfamiliar terminology.

Watching and listening to English content helps you grow your English listening skills. This assignment is all about understanding what you hear in TV shows like interviews and news reports.

Nowadays more and more of on screen content is watched on mobile devices. There is a plethora of platforms offering a variety of content. Think of Snapchat, Instagram and Vimeo. However, YouTube is still really big when it comes to high quality and varied content about any subject available. The can-do statement you'll be working on here is:

I can understand a large part of many TV programmes on topics of personal interest such as interviews, short lectures, and news reports when the delivery is relatively slow and clear.

Notice how it says: "I can understand a large part". This means it's not necessary to understand everything you hear!

Assignment

Option 1

Write a blog about the video. Think about a blog in which you explain what you learned from the video or write a bog in which you oppose something that was said in the video. You can also write about multiple videos and make a selection of must-watch videos from that channel to blog about.

Option 2

Get a teacher account on the platform: EDPuzzle. Add questions about the video to the video. Don't know how this works? We've created a tutorial for you.
